page.title: 20 THE DISUSED CANAL
page.content: In 1777 an ambitious scheme was proposed, that of connecting Leominster to Stourport, Hereford and to the Severn at Bridgnorth, by a number of canals. Nothing was done until the scheme for a canal to Stourport was revived in 1790. Work was begun on the canal but great difficulties were encountered especially in constructing a tunnel under{Putnal}field in the neighbourhood of{Orleton.}These were eventually overcome and in 1796 a length of canal was opened between {Leominster}and the coalfields near {Mamble.}In December 1796 fourteen barges arrived at the{Wharf}in Leominster. The cost of extending to Stourport was too much, and plans were abandoned. The canal was a thing of the past by 1830. The Shrewsbury and Hereford Railway Co. bought the land.
